awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Community genomic drivers of moss microbiome assembly and function in rapidly changing Alaskan ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Mosses and their associated microbes are critical components of nutrient cycling in arctic ecosystems, yet many aspects of these communities are poorly understood. Moss-associated microbes are the major source of nitrogen to support plant growth in boreal and tundra ecosystems, meaning that rates of plant growth may be highly sensitive to the activity of mosses and their microbes, which "fix" nitrogen from the atmosphere into a form useful for plant growth. Importantly, the rates of nitrogen fixation depend in complex ways upon both the genetic diversity of the mosses and their associated microbial communities (microbiomes). However, we do not know which species (moss or microbial) are responsible for rate variation in this key biogeochemical process of nitrogen fixation, nor how these communities will function respond to a warming climate. This work will test for associations between genetic variation and nitrogen fixation in order to model the response of high northern latitude biodiversity and ecosystem function to climate change. The research will provide instrumental information about how environmental change will affect Arctic ecosystems and contribute insight into the resiliency of mosses and their associated microbiomes.

The goal of the proposed work is to determine the effect of moss genetic diversity on the community assembly and function of the N-fixing microbiomes of two widespread and abundant mosses in boreal forest and arctic tundra ecosystems. The researchers will employ population genomics, functional gene sequencing, and stable isotope assays of N fixation rates along a large-scale climate gradient in Alaska that includes arctic and boreal Long-term Ecological Research (LTER) and National Environmental Observatory Network (NEON) sites. This interdisciplinary approach will enable the researchers to determine both the historical and contemporary drivers of variation in community assembly and function of this rapidly changing ecosystem, and predict how bryophyte-associated nitrogen fixation will change in a warmer climate. Thus the researchers will use moss-microbe interactions in high latitude systems as a model to inform our broader understanding of how biodiversity interacts with ecosystem function in the context of a changing climate.

por.por_cntn:
Mosses are some of the most important plants in Arctic tundra and boreal forest biomes.  They often make up more than half of the plant growth every year in these cold ecosystems. They cover the ground surface in an emerald carpet, insulating the soil from cold air temperatures in the winter and keeping soils moist in the summer. Their unique tissues contribute to the formation of thick layers of peat, a globally important reservoir of soil carbon (C). In addition to these environmental effects, mosses also create a special habitat for microbes: the diverse group of algae, fungi, and bacteria that live as epiphytes in the “moss canopy.” Some of these microbes have the enzymatic capacity to fix di-nitrogen (N) gas from the atmosphere into biologically available organic N. These moss-associated N fixers provide the largest sources of this nutrient to the ecosystem, and as such, they control the rate of moss growth, the formation of the peat, and the storage of organic C in these biomes.

In this project, we studied how mosses and microbes interacted to control N inputs to rapidly warming Arctic tundra and boreal forest ecosystems. We asked how these interactions impacted rates of N fixation at three biological scales: within populations of moss species, among species within communities, and among communities across experimental treatments and a large-scale climate gradient. To do this work, we developed a new N isotope technique for measuring very low rates of N fixation. We also designed a mobile moss lab: a growth chamber in the back of a truck where we could quickly measure N fixation rates on fresh mosses in a constant light, temperature, and moisture environment. The intellectual merit of this project emerges from our key findings.  First, our results show that every assayed moss taxa hosted microbes capable of N fixation in at least three populations sampled in our broad survey. We published the first observation of N fixation associated with several moss species. We also found instances where mosses that have previously been ignored as unimportant for fixation had large fixation rates. These finding are surprising because they challenge past studies that have venerated only a few species of mosses as the gatekeepers of ecosystem N inputs.  Our data show that many moss species can play this role, likely due to context dependent environmental factors such as the interactions among moisture, temperature, and light environment. Second, our results show that moss species identity drives composition and diversity of the moss microbiome and its capacity for N fixation. Across a large climate gradient and in experimental manipulations of vascular plant composition or climate warming, we found that microbial communities had strong fidelity to moss species and resisted change. This finding is important because it means that we can make predictions about how N inputs will respond to climate change by understanding moss response, a factor is that is much easier to measure and scale than microbial community composition or N fixation rates.

The broader impacts of this grant primarily arise from support of interdisciplinary training for faculty, graduate and undergraduate students, and a postdoc. For example, Dr. Julia Stuart carried out her dissertation research on this project.  She was trained as an ecosystem ecologist and did many of the N fixation assays that contributed to the work of our collaborators at the Universities of Florida and Colorado, as well as her own dissertation. She, in turn, worked closely with these collaborators to identify moss species, build moss phylogenies, and analyze microbial community data. Dr. Melanie Jean worked on this project as a postdoctoral researcher.  Like Julia, Melanie worked with our colleagues to identify moss species and sample, sequence, and analyze microbial community data associated with a moss transplant experiment. Both Julia and Melanie have moved on in their careers, Julia as a postdoc and Melanie as an assistant professor. Both are working with mosses and microbes in projects that draw heavily on their training in microbial community analyses. In fact, Melanie’s first major research grant focuses on understanding disturbance impacts on the moss microbiome and its associated N-fixation. This points towards the importance of this interdisciplinary training for their career paths.
